content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

```julia
function extract_julia_code(md::String)
    # Regular expression to match Julia code blocks
    pattern = r"^```julia\n((?:\s|[^\n])*)\n```"m

    # Initialize an empty string to store the extracted code
    output = ""

    # Split the markdown document into lines
    lines = split(md, '\n')

    # Loop through each line and extract code blocks
    for (i, line) in enumerate(lines)
        # Check if the current line starts a Julia code block
        m = match(pattern, line)
        if m !== nothing
            # If so, append the captured group to the output
            output *= m.captures[1] * "\n"
            # Remove the code fence from the line
            lines[i] = ""
            # Continue until we find an empty line or a line that doesn't start with `````
            while i < length(lines) && lines[i + 1] !== "" && !startswith(lines[i + 1], "```")
                i += 1
            end
        end
    end

    # Remove any leading or trailing whitespace from the output
    return strip(output)
end
```

This function uses a regular expression to match lines that start Julia code blocks. It then iterates through each line of the markdown document, appending the content of the code block to an output string while removing the code fences. Once all code blocks are extracted and concatenated, any leading or trailing whitespace is removed from the output.
